results.notes:
Tulostoma simulans Lloyd, Tulostomataceae, Tulostomatales. (Buried-stalk Puffball).

Spore sac: 6-12mm wide, roundish to acorn-shaped with small teat-like or mouth-like projection at very top; whitish up to brownish-white, sometimes with some sand or soil. Spore mass is whitish and becoming brown.
Stalk: 3-6cm long, 2-4mm thick, brownish-white up to light reddish-brown, fibrous and somewhat scaly; slightly enlarging down. It is often buried up to 90% of length.
Edibility: no data.
Habitat: rare kind; small group in pine-tree forest with some elm (Ulmus densa) and maple (Acer negúndo).
Season: June – August.

results.notes:
Location: Backyard (not landscaped)
Habitat: Oak woodland (Quercus agrifolia)
Substrate: duff, growing in a fairy ring
Cap: 2-1/2" wide x 1/2" thick, viscid, wavy, young caps broadly umbonate, older caps flattened out, wavy and some curled up & inward (like a tricorn hat), tan with white margin which bruised a pale red (The red color never changed, even days after it was picked.), white flesh, one cap had what looked like gill tissue growing on top (I don’t really know what it is, but I took detailed photos of it including a cross section).
Gills White, adnate
Stalk: 2-1/2" high x 1/2" wide, white, smooth, chalky coating (?) outside, but didn’t snap like chalk, no bruising. The next day I went out & picked a fresh one and broke it’s stipe, and it seemed to snap like chalk like a Russula.
Spores: It didn’t give me a spore print. :-(

results.notes:
Code: Bot_560/2011_DSC0186

Habitat: mixed wood, Picea abies and Fagus sylvatica dominant trees; steep mountain slope; northwest aspect; calcareous ground; in shade; partly protected from direct rain by tree canopies; average precipitations ~ 3.000 mm/year, average temperature 4-6 deg C, elevation 990 m (3.250 feet), alpine phytogeographical region.

Substratum: fallen, large, dead Fagus sylvatica lying on ground, partly still in bark.

Place: Vrsnik valley region, above the settlement ‘Na skali’, at the foot of Mt. Travniški rob, 2.135 m, East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia EC

Comments: Oudemansiella mucida is one of the most beautiful mushrooms I know. It isn’t colorful but impresses by its elegant shape and consistency. It is like made from half translucent porcelain and is wonderfully glistering in sun rays protruding through tree canopies because of its gelatinous, wet surface. It is actually a quite common species here around and almost always appears in large numbers on dead, mostly still standing Fagus sylvatica trunks, frequently appearing all along their length.

Growing in groups of many fruit bodies, more than 200 fruitbodies found in this observation. SP abundant, white.

Nikon D700/Nikkor Micro 105mm/f2.8 and Canon G11, 6.1-30mm/f2.8-4.5

Average size-pale textured pileus-bright orange stipe.

Pileus: width 60-125mm. surface uneven, textured, minutely wrinkly,

centrally depressed.

Lamellae: light yellow becoming orange with maturity. broadly spaced, intermediates always present
beginning at margin of pileus and continuing 15-25% of the distance to apex of stipe,

Latex: white, not staining, not acrid, causing a slight drying sensation when applied to the
tongue, copious.

Odor: faintly sweet.

Pileus 35-70 mm long, 15-25mm thick,
dark orange with buff granular coating, solid, flesh nearly white.

Habitat: in groups, under broad-leafed trees.

Spore deposite color: in process

results.notes: We’ve had quite a few tree falls of mature oaks and hickories in the last several years. Most of these trees were blown down, pulling up a root ball that elevates the trunk from the ground for many years. I’ve noticed a whitish curst on the lower sides and bottoms of many of the trees while the bark is still on. It’s an early colonizer along with Stereum ostrea and other bracket fungi. Unlike the brackets, the whitish crust causes the bark to loosen such that you can (with a knife and some effort) usually rip pieces of thick bark off, revealing moist degrading wood below. Today I took photos of three fallen trees, a Southern Red Oak (Quercus flacata) and two Northern Red Oaks (Q. rubra), capturing images of the crust in various states. The photos are in the order taken. No reaction to KOH.

results.notes:
Not sure what this is, apart from a cup fungi. It is similar to Cookeina.
I should add that this was found during a very hot humid period in early January (max temps up to 35 with mins above 20). There had been rain a few days ago, but most fungi were not fruiting (because of the heat?). The proposed name of Microstoma insititium does seem possible as the only record I can find of that fungi is Vanuatu, and I think this fungi has to be tropical, given that it fruits in the heat.

results.notes:
Habitat: oak woodland
Substrate: duff
Cap: 9 cm w x .75 cm thick; hemispherical to convex; chestnut brown; hygraphonous; margin lighter; glabrous; moist, but not viscid; pleasant smelling, faintly minty, caramel
Gills: adnexed or notched; concolorous with cap
Stipe: 12 cm h x .75 cm wide; fibrillose; even; pale cinnamon colored, lighter at the bottom; bottom 1/2 seems to be evenly covered with mycelium, or perhaps they are the universal veil remnants that are mentioned on mushroomexpert.com as “Fitting like a tight sock”; pleasant smelling, just like cap-first note was peppermint, then sweet and reminded me of caramel.
Spores: pale rust, like cinnamon; concolorous with cap & gills
results.location_name: Kingfisher Canyon, Avila Beach, San Luis Obispo Co., California, USA

results.notes:
A beautiful, lignicolous, primarily tropical and subtropical genus in the Cortinariaceae. An unnamed section (as of the 4th edition of Agaricales in Modern Taxonomy) contains the (then two) species with prominent lilac pigments, though more have been described since.

Substrate: on downed, well-decomposed, decorticate “Laurel” log (Ocotea sp.)

Habitat: secondary lowland tropical rainforest, regularly subject to landslides and some human disturbance. adjacent to golf course and horse pasture.

Ecoregion: Southwest Amazon Moist Forests (NT0166)

Collectors: D. Newman, P. Kaishian, D. Ettlinger & T. Padilla

results.notes: White spore print. Growing on very rotten tan bark oak (picture of log included). Lots of small fruit bodies. Biggest cap was 2 cm smallest was 0.5 cm. Spree were about 6 uM on average, we don’t have a super precise measuring set up yet as we are just taking pictures through the eye piece with our phone, we will update this number to a more accurate/precise measurement when we get a camera mount.

results.notes:
Code: Bot_579/2011_IMG7962

Habitat: mixed wood and bushes, Picea abies, Pinus Nigra, Fagus sylvatica, Fraxinus ornus, Corylus avellana dominant; calcareous, old alluvium ground; flat terrain; in shade, relatively dry and warm place; partly protected from direct rain by tree canopies; average precipitations ~ 3.000 mm/year, average temperature 8-10 deg C, elevation 420 m (1.380 feet), alpine phytogeographical region.

Substratum: Pinus nigra trunk lying on ground in its late disintegration phase.

Place: Bovec basin, southeast of Bovec golf playground, below water reservoir of Plužna power plant, East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia EC

Comments: Pholiota astragalina is a beautifully colored, worldwide spread, but not very common mushroom in Slovenia. In several European regions it is quite rare. In UK, for example, it is protected and put on their Red List. Growing solitary and in confluent groups of a few fruit bodies; SP rusty brown.

Nikon D700/Nikkor Micro 105mm/f2.8 and Canon G11, 6.1-30mm/f2.8-4.5
results.location_name: Bovec basin, East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia

results.notes:
A common, possibly undescribed parasite of palm seeds, occurring throughout low-elevation Amazon forest. Known from Ecuador, Brazil, Bolivia and Peru. A sequence from Observation 220973 points toward Penicilliopsis, but matches nothing in GenBank.

Habitat: secondary lowland tropical rainforest, regularly subject to landslides and some human disturbance. adjacent to golf course and horse pasture.

Ecoregion: Southwest Amazon Moist Forests (NT0166)

Collectors: D. Newman, P. Kaishian, D. Ettlinger & T. Padilla

results.notes:
Also collected twice in 2012, once by myself and Francisco Saavedra (Observation 238468), and again by Bolivian National Herbarium founder and former director, Stephan Beck (Observation 94324). This beautiful ascomycete is suspected of being one of the many dual pathogenic clavicipitalean fungi which prey upon both scale insects and their plant hosts. Initial inclinations were that the collection may consist of two species, but two fruiting bodies appear to be at least somewhat transitional between the lighter and darker forms. The similarity in both spore shape/length (see thread-like spores in images 5 and 7) and context tissue (images 6 and 8) also support this conclusion. As demonstrated in Observation 172217, these fungi seem to exhibit a great deal of variation among different stages of development. Unlike Ascopolyporus, the younger fruiting bodies are only slightly less carbonaceous/coriaceous than their mature counterparts, as opposed to being liquid-filled or gelatinous.

Substrate: on culms of living Chusquea sp.

Habitat: montane to high-montane, humid, secondary mountain forests

Ecoregion: Bolivian Yungas (NT0105)

Collectors: D. Newman, P. Kaishian, L. Deininger, D. Ettlinger & T. Padilla

Collection #: APA042

results.notes: After more than three years I returned to the (two) places of my previous observations of Trapelia coarctata (see observation 86132 and observation 119652). There is a wall full of big specimens (they grew a lot since my last photograph, as can be seen in the attached photos). Thallus not parasitic, epilithic, well developed but thin, continuous to rimose, not subgelatinous, lacking prothallus. Perethecia black, generally hemispherical, <0.2mm, immersed in thallus but emergent. Paraphyses absent; spores 1-celled, only two found, 17.7×6.15µm, 12×5.2µm.

Perethecial sections were not thin enough to get much detail about the involucrellum or exciple, will have to try again.

results.notes:
Melanoleuca alboflavida (Peck) Murrill, Tricholomataceae, Agaricales. (Yellowish-white Melanoleuca. Большая белая рядовка)
Big light flat fragile mushroom.
Cap: 8-15cm, broad, slightly convex or flat, sometimes a little sunken, smooth; color changed from white up to yellowish-white when old. Cap looks as a pancake (thick skin or thin flesh + gills).
Gills attached, thin and close to high density, narrow or moderately broad, white or with slightly cream coloring. Odor is weak and pleasant.
Stalk: 8-16cm long, white, 1-2cm thick, slightly enlarged down (sometimes narrowing near base), some fibrous with age and brownish-white.
Habitat: rare kind, small group scattered in shady places of well-wooded mixed forest with fir-trees, aspen and birches and rare pine-trees (wild strawberry is common).
Edibility: good when young.
Season: June-August.

results.notes:
PLUTEUS CERVINUS (SCHAEFF.) P. KUMM., PLUTEACEAE, AGARICALES. (ПЛЮТЕЙ ОЛЕНИЙ).
Cap: 8-15cm, light brown, smooth, gentle cone up to broadly convex, often with a gentle knob; some sticky in wet weather. Flesh is white.
Gills: almost free or pinching out toward stalk, moderately broad up to broad, close, whitish or cream-white up to pinkish when old.
Stalk: 6-12cm long, 1.0-2.0cm thick and enlarged toward base, sometimes bulbous, brownish-white, uneven as somewhat tiny scabers, indistinct fibrous.
Habitat: rare kind, small groups or single nearby a wood base or on the old partially rotten deciduous stumps or trunks in old mixed forest.
Edibility: edible after boiling.
Season: June-August.

results.notes:
VOLVARIELLA BOMBYCINA (SCHAEFF.) SINGER, PLUTEACEAE, AGARICALES. (TREE VOLVARIELLA, SILKY VOLVAR, ВОЛЬВАРИЕЛЛА ШЕЛКОВИСТАЯ)
Whitish fragile mushroom with cone silky cap and a sac-like cup at a stalk base
Cap: 5-10cm, white up to yellowish-white or brownish-white, cone-shaped, bell-shaped or semispherical up to convex or gentle cone, almost smooth when dry, some silky or fine velvety, sometimes spinulose with shining prominent fibers. Flesh is white up to cream-white when old.
Gills: free, close to almost crowded, moderately broad or broad, cream-white or pinkish-white when young up to cream or pink when old.
Stalk: 6-12cm long, whitish up to yellowish-white or brownish-white 1.5-2.5cm thick weakly enlarged down, hollow with aging. Lower part of stalk has spotty brownish-white or dull brown deep sac-like cup.
Veil: universal, remnants scruffy brownish-white, leaving a spot above a cap and sac-like cup on the bottom part of a stalk.
Habitat: rare kind, single minor a small group on old living deciduous trees, mainly on birches, minor at partially rotten trunks or stumps in mixed forest.
Edibility: edible with several methods of cooking (Russian internet sites).
Season: June-September.

results.notes:
Growing on moss.
Caps small, up to 3.7 cm across.
Ring superior, white and striate.
Fbs young and could not get a spore print.
Spores appeared brownish in KOH.
Few(7) spores measured ~ 8.1-9.1 X 5.8-6.0 microns, ellipsoid and with a large germ pore.
Gill cystidia appeared to be mainly cheilocystidia and ~ 65-75 X 13-15 microns, narrowly utriform.
Appeared initially to be Psathyrella longistriata but spores wider, germ pore large and gill cystidia much larger.

results.notes:
Entoloma sericeum (Bull.) Quél., Entolomataceae, Agaricales. (Энтолома шелковистая)
Cap: 3-6cm convex up to almost flat with indistinct knob or blunt knob; color sometimes has weak concentric zonality: outer ring is very light yellow-brown, middle is brown. Cap surface is smooth and some sticky in wet weather, somewhat radial hairy when dry; flesh fragile and whitish up to reddish-brown when old.
Gills: attached with pinching out (almost free), moderately close and almost distant, broad when old; color from pinkish-white up to dull reddish-brown when old.
Stalk: 8-15cm long, hollow, whitish and silky up to dull brown and fibrous (sometimes helical); 0.4-0.8cm thick.
Edibility: no data.
Habitat: small group scattered on moss in mixed forest with fir-trees, aspen and birches and rare pine-trees (wild strawberry is common).
June – August.

results.notes:
Habitat: Boulder field in semi-arid grassland habitat.

This is a tiny but distinctive Caloplaca with scant grey to rock-colored areolate thallus showing yellowing at spots of apothecia origin. Apothecia up to 1mm, concave, lecanorine, with a unique orange coloration (almost pinkish orange?). Margin thick and raised, without dark excipular ring, proper margin dominant and concolorous with disk or slightly lighter. Thalline margin present, but outside and beneath the proper margin, always with whitish-grey material on it that superficially resembles crusty pruina but I think is something else, maybe remnant thallus material? Spot tests: Thallus K-, C-; epihymenium K+R, C-; apothecial margin K+R, C- (Nash reports proper margin usually C+red-brown). Hymenium hyaline. Algal layer thick and continuous into thalline margin. Spores ellipsoid, slightly narrowed at septum at maturity. Width measurements taken at septum.
19.14×6.84µm (Q=2.8)
14.75×6.15µm (Q=2.4)
18.96×6.54µm (Q=2.9)
15.26×5.75µm (Q=2.65)
L’=17.02 W’=6.32µm. Q’=2.69

results.notes: These specimens have branched elaters, the one why to tell Trichia botrytis from Metatrichia floriformis. On the other hand the spores are about 12.5µm in diameter on average which is larger than T. botrytis spores that are said to be 9-11µm and M. floriformis at 10-12µm. Also the stems are translucent on many specimens which is a trait of M. floriformis not T. botrytis.

results.notes: Found in a mixed forest. Not my best-ever picture, but it’s exciting to get a few observations up in my new part of the world. It looks like most of the photos I’ve seen for Xylobus frustulatus, but it could also be a hypomyces on one of the more colorful ascomycetes. It doesn’t seem to clump as readily as Xylobus frustulatus usually does.

Occurs with other Caloplaca species, including observation 230785 and observation 230762

results.notes:
Infundibulicybe gibba (Pers.) Harmaja, Tricholomataceae, Agaricales (Local names: Говорушка ворончатая, Г. душистая = Clitocybe gibba)
Small whitish up to light pink – light yellow mushroom with sunken cap center up to funnel-shaped cap (clearly smaller ratio width to length as young Clitocybe flaccida has)

Cap: 3-5 cm wide, slightly convex when young, then with depressed center or wide funnel-shaped with flat thin margin, sometimes with indistinct concentric coloring, color from whitish up to light pink or light yellow; margin is lighter. Flesh is thin and white. Odor is pleasant.
Gills: descending stalk, whitish, narrow, rather close and almost distant, with short and very short additional gills.
Stalk: 3-7 cm long, 0.4-0.8cm thick, some fibrous, hollow when old, white or pinkish-white and darker in wet weather.
Edibility: edible after 20 minutes boiling.
Habitat: scattered small groups in mixed forest with fir-trees, aspen and birches and rare pine-trees (bilberry is common).
June – September
results.location_name: Serkovo Forest, Vyazniky Region, Vladimir district, Russia

results.notes:
Russula laurocerasi Melz. Russulaceae, Agaricales. (Валуй, Almond-scented Russula, Russula foetens).

Сap: 5-16cm rounded as a square head, expanding to convex or flat and slightly sunken in the centre when old; margins curved in and radial lined when old, young is slimy, than some tacky in wet weather, often glossy and shiny in dry season; color from yellowish-white or brownish-white up to yellowish-brown or brownish-yellow. Flesh is white up to light brown after some damage. Gills are attached, close and narrow when young than moderately broad and almost distant; color from white up to dull yellowish-white and brown coarse damage. Young unit has weak white acrid milk at gills.
Stalk: 3-8cm long, white up to dull yellowish-white or dull brownish-white; 1.5-4cm thick, usually slightly enlarging down than narrowing at the base, loose or hollow in the central part.
Habitat: scattered up to abundant or crowded in pine-tree forest with birches.
Edibility: good for long winter keeping (special methods of cooking using fermentation).
July – September.
results.location_name: Serkovo Forest, Vyazniky Region, Vladimir district, Russia

results.notes:
Semi fresh specimen sent to me, collected in Florida. Fairly confident this is G.ravenelii since I cannot find any melanoid bands in the context or stipe of the mushroom. Preliminary microscopy was largely inconclusive with too few spores being found, but what spores I did find were of the smooth type as I have seen in other ravenelii specimens. Though only one was shaped in a way that I would call it elongated. But only about three spores were seen and I did not bother measuring them. Once the mushroom has dried I will try to scrape more spores from the dried surface as well as try to extract some from the pore tubes.

Several tissue samples were placed on agar.
